Fig. 1 XRD patterns; (a): Ni0.1/CoAlOx-500; (b): Ni0.15/CoAlOx-500; (c): Ni0.2/CoAlOx-500; (d): Ni0.2/CoAlOx-OH; (e): Ni0.2/CoAlOx-400; (f): Ni0.2/CoAlOx-600. Fig 1 Fig. 2 TEM images of (a–c) the Ni0.2/CoAlOx-500 catalyst, (d) SAED pattern of Ni0.2/CoAlOx-500 catalyst, (e–i) EDS elemental mappings of the Ni0.2/CoAlOx-500 catalyst. Fig 2 Fig. 3 (a–c) Ni 2p, Co 2p, Al 2p XPS of catalysts at different direct reduction temperature, (d) XPS full spectrum. Fig 3 Fig. 4 (a) NH3-TPD of the catalyst Ni0.2/CoAlOx, (b) Py-IR of the catalyst Ni0.2/CoAlOx at different test temperatures. Fig 4 Fig. 5 (a) Effect of Ni y /CoAlOx (y = 0.1, 0.15, 0.2) catalysts with different Ni mass ratios on the conversion and selectivity of FFA hydrogenation. Reaction conditions: 1 g of FFA, 19 g of ethanol, 0.1 g of catalyst, temperature 150 °C, agitation speed 600 rpm, 1.5 MPa H2, 6 h duration. (b) Effect of catalysts with different calcination temperatures and methods on the conversion and selectivity of furfural hydrogenation. Reaction conditions: 1 g of FFA, 19 g of ethanol, 0.1 g of catalyst, temperature 150 °C, agitation speed 600 rpm, 1.5 MPa H2. 6 h duration. Fig 5 Fig. 6 Effect of substrate dosage on the conversion and selectivity of FFA hydrogenation. Reaction conditions: ethanol + FFA = 20 g, 0.1 g of catalyst, temperature 150 °C, agitation speed 600 rpm, 1.5 MPa H2, 6 h duration. Fig 6 Fig. 7 (a) Effect of FA molecule number on the adsorption energies of flat (b) and tilted (c–e) conformations on CoAl2O4 (311). Fig 7 Fig. 8 (a) Effect of reaction temperature on the conversion and selectivity of FFA to 2-MF. Reaction conditions: 1 g of FFA, 19 g of ethanol, 0.1 g of catalyst, agitation speed is 600 rpm, 1.5 MPa H2, 6 h duration. (b) Effect of reaction pressure on the conversion and selectivity of FFA to 2-MF. Reaction conditions: 1 g of FFA, 19 g of ethanol, 0.1 g of catalyst, agitation speed is 600 rpm, temperature 180 °C, 6 h duration. (c) Effect of reaction time on the conversion and selectivity of FFA to 2-MF. Reaction conditions: 1 g of FFA, 19 g of ethanol, 0.1 g of catalyst, agitation speed is 600 rpm, temperature 180 °C, 1.5 MPa H2. (d) Catalyst cycle testing. Reaction conditions Reaction conditions: 1 g of FFA, 19 g of ethanol, 0.1 g of catalyst, agitation speed is 600 rpm, temperature 180 °C, 1.5 MPa H2, 6 h duration. The development of green and low-cost catalysts to catalyze the conversion of biomass and its derivatives into relevant green organic chemicals and fuels is an important way to solve the energy crisis. In this work, a series of Ni/CoAlOx catalysts synthesized through calcination process with hydrotalcite as the precursor were evaluated for the selective production of 2-methylfuran (2-MF) or 1,5-pentanediol (1,5-PeD) from furfural (FFA). The Ni0.2/CoAlOx-500 exhibits the optimal activity by adjusting the Ni/(Co + Al) mass ratio and the direct reduction temperature. The mass concentration of FFA greatly influenced the product distribution, FFA preferred to produce 1,5-PeD at low concentration with a maximum selectivity of 42.8 %, and 2-MF at high concentration with a maximum selectivity of 82.6 %. DFT calculations reveal that the different substrate concentrations influence the adsorption pattern over the catalyst, with low substrate concentration tending to flat adsorption and high concentration tending to tilted adsorption. This study not only develops efficient catalysts for biomass conversion, but also reveals the mechanism of FFA directed to 2-MF and 1,5-PeD, which provides useful insights for directed conversion of biomass hydrogenation. Introduction The excessive use of traditional fossil energy by human society has caused environmental pollution and damage over the past two centuries. To solve the crisis of energy depletion and environmental problems, the development of biomass energy is necessary [1–3]. Straw, grain hulls and other agricultural byproducts are important sources of biomass energy, as they can be converted into lignocellulose after degradation [4]. Lignocellulose is mainly composed of cellulose, hemicellulose and lignin, which can be further broken down and converted into high-value chemical platform molecules such as FFA and 5-hydroxymethylfurfural [5–7]. FFA is one of the most valuable biomass-added chemicals which has been fully industrialized and can be converted into high value-added downstream chemicals such as furfuryl alcohol (FA), tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (THFA), 2-MF, 2-Methyltetrahydrofuran (2-MTHF), 1,2-pentanediol (1,2-PeD), 1,5-PeD, etc. (Scheme 1 ) under certain catalytic conditions [8–12]. As an important organic raw material, 2-MF can be used as organic solvent and gasoline fuel mix, in addition to the synthesis of pesticides, drugs, flavors and fragrances [13–15]. 2-MF can be produced by hydrogenation from FFA in gas-phase or liquid-phase. Liquid phase hydrogenation is generally preferred because of the large number of by-products in the gas phase hydrogenation reaction and the difficulty of separation [16]. Noble metals (Pt, Pd, Ru and Rh) usually show high activity and selectivity under milder conditions [17–19]. The ultra-low loading surface-doped noble metal oxide catalyst Pt/TiO2 is reported to substantially increase the formation of surface oxygen vacancies and the CO bond cleavage rate of FA side-CH2OH groups, reduce the by-products of ring hydrogenation [20]. Due to the high price of noble metals, the study of non-noble metals (Cu, Co and Ni) as alternative has become a hot topic [21,22]. Fu et al. [23] prepared Cu/SiO2 catalysts by ammonia evaporation method which showed 2-MF selectivity higher than 80 % and FFA conversion close to 100 %. The advantage over the conventional co-precipitation method is the increase in the Cu+/(Cu+ + Cu0) ratio due to the formation of a large copper silicate content during the preparation process to increase the surface acidity of the catalyst, which provides a viable strategy for the industrial preparation of 2-MF from FFA. The 20 wt.% Co-CoOx/AC prepared by an isovolumic impregnation method converted FFA to 2-MF with high yield (87.4 %) after 5 h reaction under relatively mild condition (120 ℃, 2.5 MPa of H2). The synergistic effect of Co-CoOx plays an important role in the conversion of FFA to 2-MF, and this low-cost catalyst shows good prospects for industrial applications [24]. Kalong et al. [25] prepared bimetallic Ni-Cu and Co-Cu loaded on γ-Al2O3, and the strong metal interactions can reduce the reduction temperature of the catalysts compared with the monometallic Cu, Ni, and Co, which show high selectivity in the formation of FA and 2-MF. 1,5-PeD is mainly used in the production of unsaturated polyester, polyurethane monomers, surface active agents in food, pharmaceuticals and cosmetics agent, special detergents, solvents for emulsion paints, solvents or wetting agents for inks, medical and medical (agricultural) drugs [26]. In previous studies, noble metal catalysts such as Pd [27], Rh [28], Pt [29] and Ir [30] all have high reduction capacity, which is beneficial to obtain high conversion of furfural and good selectivity of 1,5-PeD. Liu et al. [27] investigated the one-pot preparation of 1,5-PeD from FFA catalyzed by Pd-Ir-ReOx/SiO2 which achieved yield of 71 % at 373 K and 8 MPa under hydrogen atmosphere. The V-modified Ir/SiO2 (Ir-VO x /SiO2) catalyst was firstly used for the selective hydrogenolysis of THFA for the preparation of 1,5-PeD by Li et al. [30]. Due to the synergistic effect between the closely contacted Ir particles and the partially reduced isolated VO x species attached on them, the reactions can be carried out at 80 ℃ and 1 MPa. In addition, the synergistic effects between non-precious metals were also widely used in the preparation of 1,5-PeD, which were mainly concentrated in the studies of catalysts prepared with hydrotalcite-like precursors [31,32]. Zhu et al. [33] designed and synthesized Cu@MgO-La2O3 catalysts with a core-shell structure and highly dispersed Cu0 to directly hydrogenate FFA (conversion of 94.9 %) to 1,2-PeD (selectivity of 67.1 %) and 1,5-PeD (selectivity of 18.8 %). According to in-situ FT-IR experiments, it was observed that FFA adsorbed on the La2O3 basic site of the carrier through the O atoms on the furan ring and COH. This led ring opening and formation of enol intermediates, which were subsequently hydrogenated to produce 1,2-PeD and 1,5-PeD on Cu0 nanoparticles. Hydrotalcite bimetallic catalysts Cu X Co Y /Al2O3 [31] were synthesized and applied for the conversion of FA to 1,5-PeD, which showed that the yield of 1,5-PeD was positively correlated with the concentrations of CoO x , Cu0 and the alkalinity of the catalyst. Comparing the above catalysts for the production of 2-MF and 1,5-PeD, Cu, Ni and Co metals are widely used, but there is still a gap in exploring the relationship between the selective generation of 2-MF and 1,5-PeD from FFA over the same catalyst. In this work, Ni/CoAlOx catalysts were prepared by direct reduction with the mass ratio of Ni/(Co + Al) adjusted accordingly. The physicochemical properties of the catalysts were characterized by BET, XRD, SEM, TEM-EDS, XPS, NH3-TPD and Py-IR. Through the experiments, the optimum mass ratio and calcination temperature were determined and it was found that changing the substrate FFA concentration affected the product distribution. The reaction conditions including reaction temperature, hydrogen pressure and reaction time were also optimized. In addition, the adsorption patterns between substrate and catalyst at high and low substrate concentrations were simulated by density functional theory (DFT) calculations, and it was found that the substrate concentration affects the adsorption patterns between substrate and catalyst. Through simply changing the reaction conditions, 2-MF and 1,5-PeD were directionally produced from furfural over the Ni0.2/CoAlO X -500 catalyst, respectively. Experiment section Materials Furfural (99 %), 2-methylfuran (98 %), 2-methyltetrahydrofuran (99 %) were purchased from Meryer (Shanghai) Chemical Technology Co., Ltd. Furfuryl alcohol (97 %), Co(NO3)2·6H2O (99 %), Al(NO3)3·9H2O (99 %), Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (98 %) were purchased from Aladdin Reagent (Shanghai) Co., Ltd. Tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (98 %),1,5-pentanediol (98 %) and 1,2-pentanediol (98 %) were purchased from Macklin Reagent (Shanghai) Co., Ltd. NaOH (AR), Na2CO3 (AR) and Ethanol (AR) were purchased from Tianjin Jiangtian Chemical Technology Co., Ltd. H2 gas (purity 99.99 %) and hydrogen-argon gas mixture (10 vol% H2/Ar) were purchased from Tianjin Liufang Industrial Gas Co., Ltd. Catalyst synthesis Trimetallic NiCoAl catalysts were synthesized by co-precipitation. In a typical synthesis, 7 mmol of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, 27 mmol of Co(NO3)2·6H2O and 18 mmol of Al(NO3)3·9H2O at a mass ratio of Ni/(Co + Al) = 0.2 were dissolved in 100 mL deionized water and stirred to form a transparent solution, named solution A. Then 0.13 mol of NaOH and 0.065 mol of Na2CO3 were dissolved in 100 mL deionized water and stirred to form a transparent solution, named solution B. The solution A and B were added dropwise to 250 mL deionized water under vigorous stirring. The pH of this process was maintained at 10.5–11.2. Next, the mixed solution was stirred vigorously for 0.5 h and aged at 80 ℃ for 24 h. The precipitate was washed and centrifuged to the solution pH of about 7, and dried at 80 °C for 24 h. Then the precursor was directly reduced at 400 °C, 500 °C and 600 °C under 10 vol.% H2/Ar atmosphere for 6 h to obtain the catalysts Ni0.2/CoAlOx-400/500/600, respectively. Similarly, the Ni0.15/CoAlOx-500 and Ni0.1/CoAlOx-500 were obtained by changing the mass ratio of Ni/(Co + Al) to 0.15 and 0.1, respectively. For comparison of reduction methods, the precursor was first calcined at 500 °C in air for 3 h, and then reduced at 500 °C under 10 vol.% H2/Ar atmosphere for 1 h to obtain Ni0.2/CoAlOx-OH. Catalytic testing conditions The reaction was carried out in a 250 mL autoclave with a mechanical stirring speed of 600 rpm. Firstly, a certain amount of FFA, catalyst, and ethanol as solvent (FFA + ethanol = 20 g) were added to the autoclave. 1 MPa N2 was passed through three times and then H2 was charged with the corresponding pressure, and the reaction time was calculated from the temperature stabilization. At the end of the reaction, the temperature of autoclave was cooled down by passing condensate. In the catalyst cyclic stability test, after each turn of reaction, the catalyst was separated by centrifugation and washed three times with ethanol. Then the catalyst was dried in a vacuum oven at 60 °C for 8 h for the next step of the reaction. During the recovery process, about 10–15 % of the catalyst was lost, which was replenished with fresh catalyst. The products were analyzed using the Beifen Ruili GC-3420A equipped with an FID detector and a capillary column (KB-Wax, 30 m × 0.32 mm × 0.5 μm, Kromat Corporation). The reaction products are FA, THFA, 2-MF, 2-MTHF, 1,2-PeD, 1,5-PeD and a little of 1,4-pentanediol and n-pentyl alcohol. The gas phase data were analyzed using n-tridecane as an internal standard. FFA conversion and selectivity and yield to products were calculated by Eqs. (1), (2) and (3). (1) C FFA = M FFA I FFA × 100 % (2) S i = M i M FFA × 100 % (3) Y i = C FFA × S i where CFFA represents the conversion of FFA after the reaction, MFFA represents the molar amount of FFA consumed in the reaction, IFFA represents the initial molar amount of FFA, Si represents the selectivity to products, i represents the products (2-MF, 1,5-PeD, etc.). Mi represents the molar amount of products, and Yi represents the yield to products. The carbon balance of all reactions in this work is above 94 %. Characterization The specific surface area was measured by using SSA-7000 (BET) low-temperature N2 adsorption/desorption device. All samples were degassed at 300 °C for 2 h, and adsorption and desorption were measured at −196 °C. X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurement was carried out on a Bruker D8 ADVANCE X-ray using Cu-Kα for crystallinity in the 2θ range of 10–80° at a scanning speed of 5°/min. The catalyst and its layered double hydroxides (LDH) precursor were measured by field emission scanning electron microscopy (Apreo S LoVac). Transmission electron microscopy and energy dispersive spectroscopy was measured by field emission transmission electron microscopy (TEM-EDS) JEM-F200. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed using K-Alpha+ from Thermo Fisher Scientific. The analysis was calibrated by the C 1 s standard binding energy (284.8 eV). The catalysts with different Ni mass ratios were measured by Inductively Coupled Plasma Optical Emission Spectrometry (ICP-OES, Agilent 725ES & Agilent 5110). NH3-TPD test was measured on a TP-5080-B instrument. The samples were pretreated at 150 ℃ in helium atmosphere for 1 h. After cooling to 50 ℃, 10 % NH3/He mixture was injected to saturation, then He air flow was switched to purge for 1 h to remove the weak physical adsorption NH3 on the surface. Finally, the temperature rise rate was 10 ℃ /min to 750 ℃ for desorption in He atmosphere, and TCD was used to detect the removed gas. Pyridine-Infrared (Py-IR) test was measured on Bruker Tensor 27 at 150 °C, 200 °C and 350 °C. The sample was evacuated at 350 °C to remove impurity gases for 1 h and then cooled naturally to 25 °C. Subsequently, the sample was vaporized with pyridine for 30 min, evacuated to 150 °C/200 °C/350 °C for 30 min. The spectra were taken at 25 °C. Computational details Calculations of adsorption energy were carried out by using spin-polarized density functional theory with generalized gradient approximation (GGA) and Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) as implemented in Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) [34–37]. The vacuum layer was set as 15 Å to eliminate the interaction between adjacent unit cells in the z-direction. A CoAl2O4 (311)-p (1 × 1) surface slab was structured to model the spinel with cell parameters of a = 19.89 Å, b = 11.49 Å, and c = 21.26 Å. The bottom two layers of atoms were frozen, while the remaining atoms were relaxed. The cutoff energy is 500 eV, and single gamma-point grid sampling was used for Brillouin zone integration. The convergence limit of the forces was 0.02 eV/Å. The adsorption energy ( E a d ) was calculated using Eq. (4): (4) E a d = E t o t a l − E c a t − E s u b s t r a t e where E t o t a l , E c a t , and E s u b s t r a t e represent the adsorption energy of the catalyst with substrate, the catalyst and substrate, respectively. Results and discussion A series of Ni0.1/CoAlOx, Ni0.15/CoAlOx, Ni0.2/CoAlOx with different Ni mass ratios were successfully synthesized to explore the effect of Ni mass ratio (the ICP data is presented in Table S1). The catalysts Ni0.2/CoAlOx-400/500/600 were used to explore the effect of reduction temperature, and the catalyst Ni0.2/CoAlOx-OH was used to explore the effect of calcination method. The catalysts Ni0.2/CoAlOx-500-u5 was used to explore the stability of catalyst Ni0.2/CoAlOx-500. Characterizations of catalysts The physical properties of different catalysts are shown in Table 1 . The Specific surface area of the Ni0.2/CoAlOx-LDH is 99.9 m2/g. After calcination, the specific surface area of the catalyst increased and then decreased as the calcination temperature increased. By increasing the reduction temperature from 400 °C to 500 °C, the specific surface area of the sample increases from 159.6 m2/g to a maximum of 184.2 m2/g. Further increasing to 600 °C, the specific surface area decreases considerably. After subjecting Ni0.2/CoAlOx-LDH to high temperature treatment, the removal of OH−, interlayer water and interlayer CO3 2− from some of the laminates results in the creation of numerous pore structures and an increase in specific surface area. Then continued increase in temperature to 600 °C results in partial collapse of the hydrotalcite laminate structure, leading to a decrease in specific surface area [38]. The specific surface areas of Ni0.1/CoAlOx-500 and Ni0.15/CoAlOx-500 are basically the same for different Ni mass contents, while Ni0.2/CoAlOx-500 has a certain increase in specific surface area, which indicates that the optimum ratio of Ni/(Co + Al) is 0.2. The nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms of the catalysts are shown in Fig. S1, with all samples showing Type IV isotherms. Typical H3 hysteresis lines may be formed by the accumulation of laminated particles due to the collapse of laminated hydrotalcite precursors [39]. The diffraction peaks of the Ni0.2/CoAlOx-LDH (Fig. S2) were detected at 2θ of about 11.7°, 23.4°, 34.6°, 39.5°, 46.8°, 60.6° and 61.9° corresponding to the (003), (006), (012), (015), (018), (110) and (113) crystal planes of typical hydrotalcites, respectively, indicating the preparation of the precursors with a lamellar structure [40]. XRD patterns of different catalysts are shown in Fig. 1 . None of the catalyst samples show Al2O3 diffraction peaks, which may be due to the presence of Al in the samples as an amorphous or spinel Co (Ni)Al oxide phase. The XRD patterns of the catalysts with different Ni weight ratios show that the intensity of the CoAl2O4 peak (PDF#38-0814) at around 2θ = 36.8° decreases with increasing Ni mass ratio, and a significant NiO diffraction peak (PDF#78-0429) appears around 2θ = 43.5°, indicating the successful doping of Ni. From the XRD patterns of the catalysts at different calcination temperatures, it can be seen that the main peaks of these three samples are the CoAl2O4 diffraction peak and the NiO diffraction peak. With the increase of reduction temperature, the NiO peak at 2θ = 43.5° gradually shifts towards the peaks of Ni0 (PDF#89-7128) and Co0 (PDF#89-4307) around 2θ = 44.2°, and the NiO diffraction peak at 2θ = 62.8° gradually weakens, which indicates that the increase in direct reduction temperature is favorable to the conversion of metal oxides to metals. Compared to the directly reduced catalyst samples, the Ni0.2/CoAlOx-OH catalyst has a higher peak intensity and the diffraction peaks are more biased towards oxides, indicating that the samples are mainly metal oxides. The morphology of the catalyst precursor after calcination was measured by SEM (Fig. S3). It can be seen that the catalyst precursor exhibits a typical hydrotalcite lamellar structure, which further indicated the successful synthesis of the precursor. The catalyst Ni0.2/CoAlOx-500 inherits the lamellar structure of the precursor very well. Combined with the BET results, the specific surface area of the catalyst is greatly increased after calcination. The reason may be that the interlayer water molecules are burned off, resulting in larger pores, and some nickel and cobalt oxides are reduced to monomers on the surface to form metal clusters [38]. Further confirmation of the morphology and elemental distribution of the Ni0.2/CoAlOx-500 catalyst is obtained through TEM and Mapping. The average particle size of the catalyst is 3.27 nm (Fig. 2 (b)), and the presence of lattice fringes corresponding to Ni0 (111), NiO (220), CoO (220), CoO (200), and CoAl2O4 (311) suggests the existence of these metallic forms in the catalyst precursor after calcination (Fig. 2(c)). The mapping of Ni0.2/CoAlOx-500 catalysts for Ni, Co, Al and O shows that all elements are homogeneously distributed, further demonstrating the high metal dispersion of the hydrotalcite derived catalysts. Notably, well-dispersed Al provides Lewis acid sites, which facilitate the adsorption of the reaction substrate FFA [41]. In addition, the effect of direct reduction temperature on the particle size of the catalysts and the distribution of metal species is investigated (Fig. S4). The Ni0.2/CoAlOx-400 catalyst has no visible particles, and the metal species are mainly dominated by CoAl2O4, as shown from SAED pattern. The average particle size of Ni0.2/CoAlOx-600 is 4.33 nm, and the presence of Ni0 and CoAl2O4 species is evidenced by the lattice fringes, which also corresponds to XRD and XPS. The Ni0.2/CoAlOx-OH has an average particle size of 5.53 nm with a mixture of acicular and spherical particles, and the main lattice planes present are mainly dominated by CoO (200), NiO (200), and CoAl2O4 (311). Compared with the directly reduced catalyst Ni0.2/CoAlOx-500, it can be seen that the direct reduction is more favorable for the generation of Ni0 species. The larger size with increasing reduction temperature indicates that the reduction at 400 °C is not sufficient and no obvious particles are produced, while 600 °C might lead to partial hole sintering, resulting in larger particles and a decrease in the specific surface area, which also corresponds to the BET results of Ni0.2/CoAlOx-600. The impact of different calcination temperatures on the metal valence was verified by XPS (Fig. 3(a) –(d)). In the Ni 2p XPS spectra, peaks at around 852.2 and 869.3 eV are associated with Ni0 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 [42]. The peaks at around 854.8 and 871.9 eV are attributed to Ni2+ in NiO and the peaks at around 856.2 and 873.8 eV are attributed to Ni2+ in NiAl2O4 [43]. The peaks at around 862.1 and 880.1 eV are attributed to the satellite peaks of Ni 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2, respectively. As the reduction temperature increases, the content of Ni0 gradually increases, which indicates that the increase in reduction temperature facilitates the transformation of metal oxides to metal. In the Co 2p XPS spectra, the peaks at around 779.8 and 795.3 eV are respectively attributed to 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 of Co3+ (Co3O4) [24]. The peaks at around 781.2 and 796.5 eV are attributed to Co2+ (CoAl2O4) [44]. The peaks at around 787.66 and 802.35 eV are attributed to the Co 2p satellite peak. No peak in Co0 is observed as the surface Co is extremely susceptible to oxidation. In addition, the Co2+/Co3+ values increase as the increasing of calcination temperature, indicating that the increase in reduction temperature facilitates the conversion of Co3+ to Co2+. The presence of a peak of 74.3 eV in the Al 2p XPS spectrum belongs to Al3+ in CoAl2O4 [45]. These results corroborate with the XRD and TEM, indicating the presence of a large amount of CoAl2O4, some NiO, and a small amount of Ni0 in the catalyst. Additionally, the XPS profile of Ni0.2/CoAlOx-OH is supplied (Fig.S5). In the Ni 2p XPS spectra and Co 2p XPS spectra, only the oxidized states of Ni and Co are existent, and the peaks of Ni0 and Co0 are not separated, which indicates that direct reduction is more favorable for Ni0 species generation. NH3-TPD and Py-IR characterization show the catalyst Ni0.2/CoAlOx-500 acidic site species and the acid amount (Fig. 4 (a), (b)). The desorption peaks in the interval 0–250 °C, 250–450 °C and above 450 °C correspond to the weakly acidic, moderately acidic and strongly acidic sites of the catalyst, respectively. The highest acid amount of 1.8316 mmol/g is found in the case of catalysts reduced at 400 °C, which were mainly dominated by strong acids. It can be seen that Ni0.2/CoAlOx-500 and Fig. 4. (a) NH3-TPD of the catalyst Ni0.2/CoAlOx, (b) Py-IR of the catalyst Ni0.2/CoAlOx at different test temperatures Ni0.2/CoAlOx-600 are predominantly weakly and strongly acidic with a few moderately acidic sites from the Fig. 4(a). The amount of acid decreases with increasing reduction temperature due to the fact that some of the metal oxides are reduced. The weak acidity arises from the desorption of NH3 weakly adsorbed onto the weak Lewis acid sites of the metal centers, the moderate acidity arises from the interaction of NH3 with Al3+ sites of MAlOx (M = Ni, Co), and the strong acidity arises from the coordination of NH3 to the electron deficient metal oxide (CoAlOx) [46]. The presence of Lewis acid at different adsorption temperatures are confirmed by Py-IR (Fig. 4(b)). The total amount of acid in the catalyst is measured at 150 °C. Upon reaching 200 °C, some weak acids undergo decomposition, leading to a subsequent decrease in acid content. Most of the medium and weak acids decompose at 350 °C, so the acid content tested at this time is the strong acid content. The spectral bands at 1446 cm−1 and 1604 cm−1 correspond to the adsorption of pyridine at the Lewis acid (Lewis) site (CoAlOx species). The total number of acids tested at the three temperatures are shown in Table S2, it can be seen that the catalysts have an abundance of weak and strong acid sites. Combined with NH3-TPD, these acids are mainly in the form of Lewis acids. Catalysts testing and DFT calculations Catalyst activity and reaction paths are affected by different metal mass ratios. Co-based catalysts are more likely to break the COH bond of furan ring, which is more favorable for the one-step generation of 2-MF from FFA. In contrast, Ni-based catalysts are more susceptible to hydrogenation on furan ring. Therefore, Ni was added to the Co/CoAlOx catalysts in a certain mass ratio to obtain Ni0.1/CoAlOx, Ni0.15/CoAlOx and Ni0.2/CoAlOx catalysts, respectively. The results of the reaction are shown in Fig. 5 (a). The content of the intermediate product FA is gradually shrinking as the mass ratio of Ni increases. In the meantime, the content of 2-MF increases from 16.7 % to 48.4 % and the content of 1.5-PeD increases from 2.2 % to 21.5 %, which indicate that the increase of Ni content in a certain range is beneficial to improve the selectivity of 2-MF and 1,5-PeD. As analyzed by BET and XRD, increasing the Ni mass ratio significantly increases the specific surface area of the catalyst and the surface Ni0 content, which is crucial for the further conversion of the reaction intermediate FA to 2-MF and 1,5-PeD. Therefore, all subsequent test investigations of the catalysts are carried out at Ni/(Co + Al) = 0.2. Next, the catalyst calcination temperature and method were experimentally investigated. As can be seen from Fig. 5(b), the main product is FA with 98.3 % selectivity for the Ni0.2/CoAlOx-OH, while the subsequent products are basically absent. In combination with XRD and TEM, the species present on the surface of Ni0.2/CoAlOx-OH are mainly CoO and CoAl2O4. The short reduction time leads to less Ni0 on the surface of the catalyst, resulting in a weak ability to further hydrogenate the intermediate FA, and thus the main products are primarily FA. In addition, the omission of air calcination from the catalyst synthesis process promotes the formation of more surface lattice oxygen vacancies (Ov-CoOx), which will facilitate the formation of more unsaturated metal centers (Coδ+) for the adsorption of FFA [45]. From the distribution of products at different direct reduction temperatures, the conversion of FFA increases with the increase of reduction temperature. For the Ni0.2/CoAlOx-400, the products are mainly FA with 89.7 % selectivity. For the Ni0.2/CoAlOx-500, the selectivity of 2-MF and 1,5-PeD reach the maximum of 48.4 % and 21.5 % among the three reduction temperatures. At a reduction temperature of 600 °C, the selectivity of THFA is significantly increased. Combined with XRD and TEM, it can be seen that the catalyst directly reduced at 400 °C has a very low content of Ni0 species and the main species on its surface is CoAl2O4, which leads to its weak ability to further hydrogenate the intermediate FA. The catalyst reduced at 500 °C is rich in Ni0 and CoAl2O4, and the synergistic effect between the two further hydrogenates FA to produce 2-MF and 1,5-PeD. When the direct reduction temperature is 600 °C, more Ni0 sites are exposed on the surface of the catalyst, which enhance the hydrogenation of the furan ring, and thus more THFA is produced. Therefore, the direct reduction temperature of 500 °C is the best for the preparation condition of catalyst. A comparison of the literature (Table S3) shows that generally high selectivity of pentanediol has a small ratio of substrate to catalyst dosage. In this work, by increasing the substrate dosage, it is found that there is a clear regularity in the distribution of 1,5-PeD after the reaction by the level of substrate dosage (Fig. 6 ). It can be seen that the 1,5-PeD selectivity reaches 42.8 % at a substrate mass of 0.2 g with a constant catalyst dosage of 0.1 g. Thereafter, the 1,5-PeD selectivity decreased with increasing substrate mass. In summary, there is a greater tendency to produce 1,5-PeD at lower substrate concentrations. 2-MF also showed a trend of increasing and then decreasing with the weight of the substrate, and the highest 2-MF selectivity is found between 0.8–1.2 g of substrate weight. Therefore, 1 g of the FFA is used for the subsequent testing of the optimal reaction conditions for 2-MF. In addition, the catalysts for the generation of 1,5-PeD are generally dominated by weak acid sites [45], whereas the generation of 2-MF is dominated by strong acids [24]. The Ni0.2/CoAlOx-500 catalyst possesses abundant weak and strong acid sites, mainly in the form of Lewis acids (from the NH3-TPD and Py-IR). This may be the key to the catalytic production of 2-MF and 1,5-PeD by Ni0.2/CoAlOx-500 under different conditions. DFT calculations were carried out to determine the effect of substrate weight concentration on the adsorption mode of the catalyst. Since FA is an intermediate product of 2-MF and 1,5-PeD, the calculation process can be simplified by FA as the adsorption object. The adsorption energies and adsorption configurations of different numbers of FA molecules on CoAl2O4 are shown in Fig. 7 . The adsorption energy of a FA molecule at low concentration was calculated separately for flat and tilted, where the flat adsorption energy (−1.147 eV) is much larger than the tilted adsorption energy (−0.674 eV). When increasing the number of FA molecules, the degree of tilting increases due to spatial effects and intermolecular forces, and the adsorption energy of individual FA molecules also increases. The adsorption energy of a single molecule is −1.265 eV when the number of FA molecules is 3, which is already greater than the adsorption energy of one FA molecule in flat adsorption, indicating that the concentration of FA greatly affects the adsorption conformation. Moreover, CC was excluded as the binding sites for FA and CoAl2O4 (311) in Fig. S8, which have lower adsorption energy. Therefore, in flat adsorption, the active site on the catalyst is more likely to contact COC on the furan ring and more likely to generate 1,5-PeD. In the tilt adsorption, the active site is more accessible to the COH on the furan ring, so the selectivity of 2-MF is higher, which also provides guidance for the elaboration of the reaction mechanism below. Conditional optimization and cycle testing for 2-MF The conversion and product distribution are shown Fig. 8 (a) during the hydrogenolysis of FFA over the Ni0.2/CoAlOx-500 at different temperatures. The results demonstrate that with an increase in reaction temperature from 120 °C to 180 °C, there is a corresponding increase in FFA conversion from 84.1 % to 99.9 %, along with a significant rise in 2-MF selectivity from 7.2 % to 82.6 %. THFA and 1,5-PeD show volcano-like curves. It has been reported that the adsorption geometry of FFA is susceptible to the reaction temperature [47]. At higher temperatures, the furan ring may tilt away from the surface and the intermediate product FA is only bonded to the catalyst surface via the C atom on the side chain, which weakens the bonding of the C atom to the hydroxyl group, ultimately leading to easier 2-MF formation and inhibiting the formation of the by-product THFA. Therefore, 180 °C is the optimum temperature condition for the formation of 2-MF from FFA. The effect of different initial hydrogen pressures (0.5–2 MPa) on FFA conversion and product selectivity is shown in Fig. 8(b). In the low H2 pressure condition (0.5 MPa), a small part of the FFA is not completely converted and most of the products are FA. The FFA is basically fully converted and there is a maximum point of activity for 2-MF (1.5 MPa) when the pressure is increased from 1 MPa to 2 MPa. There is a large decrease in 2-MF selectivity (from 82.6 % to 55.2 %) when the pressure is increased to 2 MPa, which indicates that an appropriate pressure can improve the selectivity of 2-MF. When the H2 pressure is more than 1.5 MPa, further increase in the selectivity of THFA and 1,5-PeD indicates that the reaction will be more inclined to hydrogenation on the furan ring. The variation in FFA conversion and product yield at different reaction times is shown in Fig. 7(c). The FFA reaction is basically complete at 2 h from the time-varying product distribution. Since the yield line of FA is volcanic, it can be inferred that FA is an intermediate product of the reaction. Furthermore, 2-MF yields of 92 % can be achieved under the same conditions with FA instead of substrate (Table S4), which also reflects the correctness of the reaction pathway from the side. Replacing the substrate with THFA, the reaction barely proceeds, which indirectly negates THFA as an intermediate in the formation of 1,5-PeD. On the whole, there is little change in THFA and 1,5-PeD yields from 2 h to 8 h, and it can be thought that THFA does not open the ring to produce 1.5-PeD over the Ni0.2/CoAlOx-500 catalyst. The results of the Ni0.2/CoAlOx-500 cycle test are shown in Fig. 8(d). Following five cycles, the FFA can still be completely converted and the 2-MF selectivity decreases from 82.6 % to 78.9 %, which indicates that the good stability of the catalyst. The increase in the intermediate product FA may be due to the partial oxidation of the metal on the catalyst surface by air during the collection of the catalyst after the reaction, which also explains the slight decrease in the content of 2-MF. The BET data and XRD data of the catalyst Ni0.2/CoAlOx-500 before and after cyclic test are shown in Table 1, Figs. S6 and S7. After five cycles, the specific surface area, particle size and composition of the catalyst don't change significantly, which indicates that the catalyst has good cyclic stability. Catalytic mechanism Based on the above experimental data, catalyst characterization and DFT simulations, the reaction mechanism for the conversion of 2-MF and 1,5-PeD by FFA over Ni0.2/CoAlOx catalysts is revealed. Fig. 9 (1) shows the mechanism of conversion of FFA to 2-MF in an environment of high substrate concentration. First, CO on FFA is adsorbed to the CoAlOx active site on the catalyst, CoAlOx is known by Py-IR to provide Lewis acid sites that can facilitate the adsorption of oxygen containing groups. Meanwhile, after the adsorption of metal Ni and Co, H2 is desorbed to activated H atoms. Subsequently, hydrogen overflow from the activation to CO hydrogenolysis to produce FA. According to the DFT calculations, at high concentrations, due to the spatial effects between molecules and the interactions among FA molecules, the situation depicted in Fig. 8(a) readily occurs. This leads to a greater likelihood of contact between the COH group on the chain and the COC group on the ring with the active sites of the CoAlOx catalyst. As a result, the activated hydrogen atom comes into contact with the COH bond, leading to dehydrogenation and the production of 2-MF and water molecules. Subsequently, the products desorb from the catalyst, completing the catalytic cycle. Fig. 9(2) shows a pathway of FFA to 1,5-PeD at low substrate concentrations. The process of FFA generation to FA is as described above, and according to the DFT calculations above, at low concentrations, FA molecules are more likely to undergo a parallel adsorption conformation as shown in Fig. 9(2). The COC on the furan ring is more likely to contact the CoAlOx active site on the catalyst. Then the activated hydrogen atom hydrogenates the COC group to form the enol intermediate, followed by CC double bond hydrogenation to form 1,5-PeD, and finally 1,5-PeD is desorbed from the catalyst to complete the cycle. The concentration of the substrate affects the adsorption conformation of the substrate on the catalyst and the change in conformation can lead to different contact sites for the substrate and thus differences in the product can occur. In addition, the prepared catalyst Ni0.2/CoAlOx-500 provides an abundance of active sites, which is an important basis for the realization of both catalytic pathways. Conclusion A hydrothermal co-precipitation synthesis strategy has been constructed to prepare trimetallic NiCoAl catalyst to facilitate the upgrading of FFA from biomass, in which the content of Ni0 can be easily increased by direct calcination reduction. The Ni0.2/CoAlOx-500 catalyst enriched with both weak and strong acidic sites exhibits an excellent catalytic performance for the hydrodeoxygenation of FFA with a maximum 2-MF yield of 82.6 % at 180 ℃ for 6 h and a maximum 1,5-PeD yield of 42.8 % at 150 °C for 6 h. The results of DFT calculations show that the adsorption configuration between the substrate and the catalyst is influenced by the substrate concentration, with tilted adsorption occurring at high substrate concentration more likely to produce 2-MF and flat adsorption occurring at low substrate concentration more likely to produce 1,5-PeD. Therefore, this work demonstrates that substrate concentration has a dramatic effect on product distribution, and the present catalytic system also provides a path for reactions of targeted upgrading of biomass to high-value products. coredata.dc:description: The development of green and low-cost catalysts to catalyze the conversion of biomass and its derivatives into relevant green organic chemicals and fuels is an important way to solve the energy crisis. In this work, a series of Ni/CoAlOx catalysts synthesized through calcination process with hydrotalcite as the precursor were evaluated for the selective production of 2-methylfuran (2-MF) or 1,5-pentanediol (1,5-PeD) from furfural (FFA). The Ni0.2/CoAlOx-500 exhibits the optimal activity by adjusting the Ni/(Co + Al) mass ratio and the direct reduction temperature. The mass concentration of FFA greatly influenced the product distribution, FFA preferred to produce 1,5-PeD at low concentration with a maximum selectivity of 42.8 %, and 2-MF at high concentration with a maximum selectivity of 82.6 %. DFT calculations reveal that the different substrate concentrations influence the adsorption pattern over the catalyst, with low substrate concentration tending to flat adsorption and high concentration tending to tilted adsorption. This study not only develops efficient catalysts for biomass conversion, but also reveals the mechanism of FFA directed to 2-MF and 1,5-PeD, which provides useful insights for directed conversion of biomass hydrogenation.
coredata.dc:title: Controlled targeted conversion of furfural to 1,5-pentanediol or 2-methylfuran over Ni/CoAlOx catalyst
